title: John Randolph Grymes
text:
John Randolph Grymes (December 14, 1786 – December 3, 1854) was a <a href="New%20Orleans">New Orleans</a> attorney, member of the <a href="Louisiana">Louisiana</a> state legislature, U.S. attorney for Louisiana district, and "<a href="aide-de-camp">aide-de-camp</a>" to General <a href="Andrew%20Jackson">Andrew Jackson</a> during the <a href="Battle%20of%20New%20Orleans">Battle of New Orleans</a>.
Early life.
Grymes was born on December 14, 1786, in <a href="Orange%20County%2C%20Virginia">Orange County, Virginia</a> into several of the <a href="First%20Families%20of%20Virginia">First Families of Virginia</a>. He was a son of Benjamin Grymes (–1805) and Sarah Robinson (1755–1831). Among his siblings were <a href="Philip%20Grymes">Philip Grymes</a>, Thomas Grymes, Elizabeth Pope (<a href="n%C3%A9e">née</a> Grymes) Braxton and Peyton Grymes.
His paternal grandparents were Mary (née <a href="Randolph%20family%20of%20Virginia">Randolph</a>) Grymes and Col. Philip Ludwell Grymes, a <a href="List%20of%20members%20of%20the%20Virginia%20House%20of%20Burgesses">member</a> of the <a href="Virginia%20House%20of%20Burgesses">Virginia House of Burgesses</a>. Like <a href="Thomas%20Jefferson">Thomas Jefferson</a> and <a href="Robert%20E.%20Lee">Robert E. Lee</a>, Grymes was a descendant of <a href="William%20Randolph">William Randolph</a> and Mary Isham, through his maternal grandmother's father, <a href="John%20Randolph%20%28politician%29">Sir John Randolph</a>, the youngest son of William and Mary. His uncle and namesake, John Randolph Grymes, was a <a href="Loyalist%20%28American%20Revolution%29">loyalist</a> during the <a href="American%20Revolution">American Revolution</a> who joined the <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> under the former <a href="List%20of%20colonial%20governors%20of%20Virginia">Royal Governor of Virginia</a> <a href="John%20Murray%2C%204th%20Earl%20of%20Dunmore">Lord Dunmore</a>. His maternal grandparents were Sarah (née Lister) Robinson and Peter Robinson, who was educated at <a href="Oriel%20College%2C%20Oxford">Oriel College, Oxford</a> and was a member of the Virginia House Burgesses between 1758 and 1761. His uncle, <a href="Christopher%20Robinson%20%28Upper%20Canada%20politician%29">Christopher Robinson</a>, was a <a href="United%20Empire%20Loyalist">United Empire Loyalist</a> and the father of <a href="Sir%20John%20Robinson%2C%201st%20Baronet%2C%20of%20Toronto">Sir John Robinson, 1st Baronet</a>, the <a href="Chief%20Justice%20of%20Upper%20Canada">Chief Justice of Upper Canada</a>. Their ancestor, also named <a href="Christopher%20Robinson%20%28planter%20and%20politician%29">Christopher Robinson</a>, came to Virginia about 1666 as secretary to Sir <a href="William%20Berkeley%20%28governor%29">William Berkeley</a>, <a href="Governor%20of%20Virginia">Governor of Virginia</a>. His grandfather was a brother of <a href="John%20Robinson%20%28Virginia%20politician%2C%20born%201705%29">John Robinson</a>, Speaker of the House of Burgesses, and <a href="Beverley%20Robinson">Beverley Robinson</a>, also a loyalist leader.
Career.
In 1808, Grymes arrived in New Orleans. On May 4, 1811, Grymes was appointed to replace his deceased brother <a href="Philip%20Grymes">Philip</a> as the <a href="United%20States%20District%20Court%20for%20the%20Western%20District%20of%20Louisiana">U.S. attorney for Louisiana district</a>, serving until December 1814, when he resigned his post to represent the pirate <a href="Jean%20Lafitte">Jean Lafitte</a>. During the <a href="War%20of%201812">War of 1812</a>, Grymes served as "<a href="aide-de-camp">aide-de-camp</a>" to General <a href="Andrew%20Jackson">Andrew Jackson</a> during the <a href="Battle%20of%20New%20Orleans">Battle of New Orleans</a>.
As an attorney, he was law partners with <a href="Edward%20Livingston">Edward Livingston</a> and was one of Jackson's lawyers in the case over the <a href="Second%20Bank%20of%20the%20United%20States">Second Bank of the United States</a>, he opposed <a href="Daniel%20Webster">Daniel Webster</a> in court against <a href="Myra%20Clark%20Gaines">Myra Clark Gaines</a>, and, reportedly, he earned $100,000 in the batture (or alluvial) land case against Edward Livingston.
Grymes was a member of the "New Orleans Association" which included attorneys Edward Livingston and <a href="Abner%20L.%20Duncan">Abner L. Duncan</a>, merchant John K. West, smuggler <a href="Pierre%20Lafitte">Pierre Laffite</a>, and pirate <a href="Jean%20Laffite">Jean Laffite</a>. Grymes was also a founding member of <a href="The%20Boston%20Club">The Boston Club</a>, a private <a href="gentlemen%27s%20club">gentlemen's club</a> in New Orleans.
Personal life.
On December 1, 1822, Grymes married Cayetana Susana "Suzette" (née Bosque) Claiborne, widow of the first <a href="List%20of%20Governors%20of%20Louisiana">Louisiana Governor</a> <a href="William%20C.%20C.%20Claiborne">William C. C. Claiborne</a>, and daughter of Felicidad Fangui and Bartolomé Bosque, a wealthy Spanish merchant and ship owner. From her first marriage, she was the mother of two: Sophronia Louise Claiborne (the wife of <a href="Antoine%20James%20de%20Marigny">Antoine James de Marigny</a>, the son of <a href="Bernard%20de%20Marigny">Bernard de Marigny</a>) and Charles W. W. Claiborne, the Clerk of the <a href="United%20States%20District%20Court%20for%20the%20Western%20District%20of%20Louisiana">U.S. Court in New Orleans</a>. Together, they lived at 612 Royal Street in the <a href="French%20Quarter">French Quarter</a> of New Orleans, and were the parents of four children, including:
Grymes died in New Orleans on December 3, 1854. His widow survived him by over a quarter century before her death in Paris August 6, 1881.
Descendants.
Through his son Alfred, he was a grandfather of John Randolph Grymes (1859–1929), who married his half first cousin once removed, Sophronie Coale Thomas, and Mabel Grymes Heneberger (1861–1883), who married Lucien Guy Heneberger, a U.S. Naval Surgeon who served as head of the <a href="United%20States%20Naval%20Academy">Naval Hospital at Annapolis</a>. Mabel died after giving birth to their first child, and Heneberger built the <a href="Mabel%20Memorial%20Chapel">Mabel Memorial Chapel</a> and Mabel Memorial Schoolhouse in <a href="Harrisonburg%2C%20Virginia">Harrisonburg, Virginia</a> in her honor.
Through his daughter Athenais, he was a grandfather of <a href="Medora%20de%20Vallombrosa%2C%20Marquise%20de%20Mor%C3%A8s">Medora von Hoffmann</a> (1856–1921), who married <a href="Marquis%20de%20Mores">Marquis de Mores</a>, a French-born nobleman who was a <a href="frontier">frontier</a> ranchman in the <a href="Badlands">Badlands</a> of <a href="Dakota%20Territory">Dakota Territory</a>; he was assassinated in Algeria in 1896. He was also the grandfather of Pauline Grymes (1858–1950), who married the wealthy German industrialist Baron Ferdinand von Stumm whose family owned the <a href="Neunkirchen%2C%20Saarland">Neunkirchen</a> Iron and Steelworks in <a href="St.%20Petersburg%2C%20Russia">St. Petersburg, Russia</a> in 1878.
Legacy.
<a href="Grymes%20Hill%2C%20Staten%20Island">Grymes Hill, Staten Island</a>, is named after Suzette Grymes, who settled there in 1836 with her children. She built a mansion on the hill there known as "Capo di Monte" ("Top of the Mountain").
